'STORMERS BEGIN
SEASON WITH RALLY
Over A Hundred Undergraduates and Alumni Turn Out
PLAY ANNOUNCED
"The Black Flamingo" To Be
Given At Lyric December
5th and 6th
Last night at 8:30 o'clock in the
Barn the Johns Hopkins University
dramatic club, the Barnstormers,
inaugurated the current season with
their first official meeting and rally.
The gathering, which was attended by over a hundred people,
was called to order by President
Farinholt, who welcomed the candidates with a few words. The actual
business of enrolling candidates was
quickly taken care of in order to
dedicate the remaining part of the
evening to enlightening speeches,
refreshments and a general gettogether.

SENIOR CLASS
HOLDS NOMINATIONS
Seniors met for the first
time this year in the C. E.
Hall yesterday and nominated the following men for
the class offices: For president, Lockard, Parks, Heinzerling ; for secretary,Abram,
McDonald, Dowell, Rutherford, Peake, Schwartz; for
treasurer, Kyle, Burk; for
sergeant-at-arms, Towbi n,
Halsey.
Election of officers and honorary president will be held
next Thursday, at which time
the customary voting in of
men eligible for membership
in the Senior Class will take
place. Such men as threeyear engineers and others
making the University in three
years are requested to attend
the meeting.

DR. OLIVER ADDRESSES
DORMITORY STUDENTS

SHOULD READ MORE
Dean Berry Asks New Men to
Make New System a
Success
Yesterday at the first assembly
for both freshman and sophomores,
President Joseph S. Ames and
Dean E. \V. Berry addressed the
students. The C. E. Hall was filled
to capacity and approximately
twenty-five men were left without
chairs.
After the singing of the University Ode, Francis Warlow, president of the Student Council, introduced President Ames.
Be Serious

Dr. Ames started out by giving
reasons for being so serious when
he spoke to the students. In the
first place he said that he was naturally serious and especially so in
academic matters. He expressed
the wish that all students should be
a bit more serious in regards to
their college education. The students should find out which things
are the more worth while, those of
the soul or of the body. Dr. Ames
said that if the students do not
make up their minds as to what
they are striving for and then go
after that thing, their time is completely wasted. Above all he emphasized the fact that the men must
not forget the things of the spirit,
such as art, and music, and good
books.
Leisure Reading

In regard to books Dr. Ames
said that all students should do a
lot of leisure reading, that man who
has gone thru college without doing any reading in his spare time
has lost a wonderful thing. It is
through how a man spends leisure
time that his character may be read.
He advised the men to select one
author and read all of his works
during a winter. If these things
were done, Dr. Ames said he would
feel satisfied.
Dr. Berry

Mr. Warlow then introduced
Dean Berry.
Dean Berry opened by saying that
he hoped the Freshman class would
live up to their reputed good looks
in every way. Having spent the last
quarter of a century studying
the growth of organisms, he was
especially interested in this subject
of the spirit, and said that the
danger of our civilization being destroyed by our machines was foolish
as long as we continued to use our
reason and improve our minds.
Scholarship

He asked the men this year to try
to do well scholastically to help
prove the good side of the new
plan. However, the real quality of

HOPKINS ELEVEN TO
MEET LEHIGH TEAM
Game to Be Played Tomorrow
Afternoon
DEFEATED P. M. C.
Severe Test Ahead for Black
And Blue
With their 39-6 conquest of Upsala College behind them, the Hopkins team will get a real test tomorrow afternoon when they meet the
Lehigh University eleven at Homewood. Whether or not last week's
win was merely a victory over a
weak team or the Jays really have
plenty of power in their attack and
a sturdy defense will be revealed
when the teams line up at 8:30 p.m.
There is little doubt but that
Lehigh will bring a strong team
here. Last week they ran roughshod over the Pennsylvania Military College eleven to score a
25-to-0 victory. As Hopkins plays
the Chester cadets on November
8th, the game tomorrow will serve
as a contemporary comparison of
the cadets and the Jays, although,
of course, it is too early in the
season to predict any results.
Jays Lost Last Year

Last year Hopkins opened their
season with Lehigh and, after
travelling up to Bethlehem, went
down to a 26-0 defeat. Without a
doubt, Lehigh is stronger than last
year. Just how much more so will
be seen.
Local fans are regaining some
of the enthusiasm which had been
lost during the past two seasons.
All agree that the Jays are much
stronger than last fall. Upsala was
unable to stop the locals' offensive
drives and the New Jersey attack
could not penetrate the Black and
Blue defense. Late in the last quarter they managed to gain against
the reserves, but against the varsity
they were held to a standstill.
Complaints

Although the majority of fans
seemed pleased with the lighting
system at Homewood, there are
quite a few discussions on the advisability of night football. Several
have complained that the use of
artificial light has robbed the game
of numerous thrills. However, it
is only fair to state that with one
or two exceptional plays, the Upsala
game last week would not have been
thrilling either in daylight or at
night.
Full Strength

Having come through the game
last week with only a few • minor
casualties, the Jays should be able
to present their full strength when
the teams line up for the opening
whistle. Mistakes were made last
week, as was to be expected. These
will be corrected during the week
and several rough spots will be
ironed out in the daily practices.
Jack Turnbull showed up in fine
style against the New Jerseyites
and was ably supported by Hudert,
Bauer, Reid and Reynolds. This
quintet of backs showed promise of
making things very uncomfortable
for opposing defenses as the season
progresses. On the line, Bialaskorsky seems to have taken up
where he left off last year when his
stellar work earned him a place at
tackle on the mythical All-Maryland
eleven. Levy, Helm, Weitzel and
Curtwright also played well. The
recovering of fumbles made by the
visitors showed that the Jays were
alert and "on their toes," while the
conspicuous absence of Jay fumbles
spoke well for their work when the
ball was in their possession.
All in all, there should be an interesting afternoon at the field to(Continued on page 4, col. 4)

EDITORIALS
CLASS ELECTIONS
N the editorial columns of various college newspapers we often meet
with pleas for a larger number of students to vote in the election of
class officers. At Hopkins we face the same problem. Only a small
fraction of the members of any class cast their ballots in the annual
elections. Then when the results are announced, the cry of dirty
campus politics inevitably arises. Let us investigate the matter.
As the time for nominations draws near there are usually one or
two prominent men in the class who are well qualified to fill a particular office. These men are nominated without any political move.
Some ambitious fraternity or other group will see to it that one of
its less able men is nominated. Election day arrives. The fraternities
or friends of the able men usually do little or no electioneering. They
take it for granted that their candidate will be elected because of his
qualifications for the office. On the other hand, the supporters of the
man not so well qualified, realizing that votes must be secured, proceed
to electioneer. Their methods _need not be discussed as they are well
known to every student. The votes are counted and a so-called "dark
horse" is elected. The cry of dirty politics arises.
This situation may easily be remedied. At present it is comparatively
easy to elect a man to an office which he does not deserve because
such a small number of votes are necessary to carry the election. The
very ones who complain the most are generally to blame. Some of
them say that the situation is hopeless and do not vote at all; others
cast their own ballot but never urge others to show their preference
on the ticket. If every student who is interested in any activity of
his class should vote, and see to it that others did the same, more able
class officers would undoubtedly be elected. At the same time we
would like to suggest that the able candidates be more actively supported by their friends.

BARNSTORMERS
night the Barnstormers held their annual rally. The results of
L AST
the changes of policy of the organization this year will be of

interest to all undergraduates. The chief problem is whether or not a
finished production can be prepared during the first semester. There
will be fewer conflicts the first week in December than during March
or April, and a larger audience may be expected. On the other hand,
concentrated work during October and November will be demanded.
The wiseness of this move is therefore questionable.
The innovation of having girls to take the female parts will remove
many a laugh from the annual show. On the other hand, it makes a
much better production possible. The NEWS-LETTER congratulates the
Barnstormers on attempting something new among the conservative
Hopkins activities, and wishes them the greatest success.

CONGRATULATIONS
improvements in the main reading room of Gilman Hall are
ASnow
complete, it is time to congratulate those responsible for

giving Hopkins one of the most beautiful college reading rooms in the
country. The bequest of Mrs. Mary King Carey, which made the erection of the windows possible, is certainly appreciated. The work of
Mr. J. Scott Williams in designing the windows was of the highest
order. Mr. W. L. Ross is deserving of praise for generously providing the means of making the furniture fit the beautiful windows.
Lastly, the endeavors of the University librarian, Dr. John Calvin
French, in supervising the work merit congratulations from all those
connected with Hopkins.

THE NIGHT FOOTBALL RACKET
By GEORGE E. BANKS,JR.'29
After much preliminary hoopla,
strong-armed publicity, and a brilliant display of showmanship, night
football has finally made its debut
on the Homewod campus. To advertise this nocturnal spectacle, the
master minds of the Athletic Department employed an ingenious device. They hired the steam calliope
which, for many months, has been
touring the downtown boulevards
making life miserable for the good
citizens of Baltimore. This same
contraption has been used to exploit the charms of the "Kuddling
Kuties" at the Gayety Theatre and
the antics of the demented cuckoos
who have been shuffling around
Carlin's dance pavilion for several
thousand hours. Thus, Hopkins
athletics take their place in the spotlight with the seductive burlesque
babies of East Baltimore Street and
the bleary-eyed nit-wits who are
participating in the dance marathon.
In spite of the calliope, several
thousand chilly football fans wended their way to Homewood field,
last Saturday night, to see what this
night football business is all about,
if anything. For two long hours,
they sat on concrete slabs, cooled
to the temperature of icebergs, and
watched something that looked a little bit like a football game. They
faced the cruel glare of six immense
arc lights which dazzled the eyes
like airport beacons. After the contest, plenty of the folks who followed the pied pipings of the calliope were wishing that they had
gone to a cozy movie parlor or
stayed home beside the steam radiator and listened to Rudy Vallee on
the radio. The next morning, when
they awake with stiff necks, sore
throats and snuffling noses, they
were even more certain that night
football is not a healthful diversion
for the humble spectator.
The big mystery, which no one
scems able to explain, is just why it
is necessary for Hopkins to play
football games after sunset. Certainly, there is no appreciable gain
to be made at the box office. Almost
every business man or factory laborer has a half-day holiday on Saturday. The student body does not
have to attend classes or work in
laboratories on Saturday afternoon.
Just as many people can attend in
the afternoon as night. Of course,
if the game conflicts with a strong
counter attraction at the Stadium,
there is some justification for an
evening game. But this situation
will occur but once this season.
Homewood Field has always provided a perfect setting for afternoon football games. The rich,
brilliant autumnal foliage of Wyman's Park forms a picturesque
background. The brisk, snappy
quality of the atmosphere is a real
tonic. One's eyes sparkle and cheers
for dear, old Alma Mater leap from
the throat spontaneously. The
football fan feels that it's good to
be alive. He trudges off to dinner
with a keen appetite, whetted by the
crisp, invigorating air.
Now, compare the afternoon
brand of weather with the dank,
chilly atmosphere which characterizes October and November nights.
The air is cold and penetrating. The
brightly colored trees are transformed into black, forbidding shadows. And the chances are two to
one that the fan will awaken the
next morning with a kink in his
neck.
Night football, as it is now being

played at Homewood, is grossly unfair to the visiting team. Upsala
gridders were muffing lots of balls
during the preliminary practice.
During the game, they seemed bewildered by the strong glare of the
arc lights.
On the other hand, the Jays can
practice under the lights every evening if they find it desirable to perfect their night game. They can
accustom themselves to the playing
conditions and shake off the strange
feeling of "unreality" which the
strong lights create.
But the visiting team, entirely
unaccustomed to these moonlight
monkeyshines, arrives on the scene
and has only twenty or thirty minutes to get used to the tricky playing conditions. Visiting players now
have a gilt-edge alibi to offer for
their defeats. There's small glory
awaiting the Jays in conquering
mystified foes that can't catch a
white football that looks as big as
a house. No wonder the Lehigh
team refused to play tomorrow's
contest in the blinding glare of the
arc lights.
In its present stage of development, night football takes its place
beside miniature golf as a freakish
novelty which is destined to live a
short life. For a little while, we
can expect to witness good crowds
at these night contests. But, after
the initial thrill has faded away, the
loyal fans will clamor for real football, played in the warm sunshine.
Wide open spaces will start to appear in the stands. Then, the wise
men who have to pay the electric
company's bill for the lighting system, will want to put a mortgage on
Gilman Hall.

Neighborhood Churches
To Hold Reception
The Johns Hopkins University
Neighborhood Churches are giving
a reception to the students of Hopkins and Goucher College this evening at 8:00 o'clock at the Friends'
Meeting House, 3107 North Charles
Street.
John L. Hill, of Nashville, Tenn.,
will be the speaker. Refreshments
will be served. The reception is
under the auspices of ten of the
neighboring churches, and all of the
students of the University are cordially invited.

"The Black Flamingo" To Be

5th and 6th
Last night at 8:30 o'clock in the
Barn the Johns Hopkins University
dramatic club, the Barnstormers,
inaugurated the current season with
their first official meeting and rally.
The gathering, which was attended by over a hundred people,
was called to order by President
Farinholt, who welcomed the candidates with a few words. The actual
business of enrolling candidates was
quickly taken care of in order to
dedicate the remaining part of the
evening to enlightening speeches,
refreshments and a general gettogether.

DR. OLIVER ADDRESSES
DORMITORY STUDENTS

SHOULD READ MORE
Dean Berry Asks New Men to
Make New System a
Success
Yesterday at the first assembly
for both freshman and sophomores,
President Joseph S. Ames and
Dean E. \V. Berry addressed the
students. The C. E. Hall was filled
to capacity and approximately
twenty-five men were left without
chairs.
After the singing of the University Ode, Francis Warlow, president of the Student Council, introduced President Ames.
Be Serious

Dr. Ames started out by giving
reasons for being so serious when
he spoke to the students. In the
first place he said that he was naturally serious and especially so in
academic matters. He expressed
the wish that all students should be
a bit more serious in regards to
their college education. The students should find out which things
are the more worth while, those of
the soul or of the body. Dr. Ames
said that if the students do not
make up their minds as to what
they are striving for and then go
after that thing, their time is completely wasted. Above all he emphasized the fact that the men must
not forget the things of the spirit,
such as art, and music, and good
books.
Leisure Reading

In regard to books Dr. Ames
said that all students should do a
lot of leisure reading, that man who
has gone thru college without doing any reading in his spare time
has lost a wonderful thing. It is
through how a man spends leisure
time that his character may be read.
He advised the men to select one
author and read all of his works
during a winter. If these things
were done, Dr. Ames said he would
feel satisfied.
Dr. Berry

Mr. Warlow then introduced
Dean Berry.
Dean Berry opened by saying that
he hoped the Freshman class would
live up to their reputed good looks
in every way. Having spent the last
quarter of a century studying
the growth of organisms, he was
especially interested in this subject
of the spirit, and said that the
danger of our civilization being destroyed by our machines was foolish
as long as we continued to use our
reason and improve our minds.
Scholarship

He asked the men this year to try
to do well scholastically to help
prove the good side of the new
plan. However, the real quality of

HOPKINS ELEVEN TO
MEET LEHIGH TEAM
Game to Be Played Tomorrow
Afternoon
DEFEATED P. M. C.
Severe Test Ahead for Black
And Blue
With their 39-6 conquest of Upsala College behind them, the Hopkins team will get a real test tomorrow afternoon when they meet the
Lehigh University eleven at Homewood. Whether or not last week's
win was merely a victory over a
weak team or the Jays really have
plenty of power in their attack and
a sturdy defense will be revealed
when the teams line up at 8:30 p.m.
There is little doubt but that
Lehigh will bring a strong team
here. Last week they ran roughshod over the Pennsylvania Military College eleven to score a
25-to-0 victory. As Hopkins plays
the Chester cadets on November
8th, the game tomorrow will serve
as a contemporary comparison of
the cadets and the Jays, although,
of course, it is too early in the
season to predict any results.
Jays Lost Last Year

Last year Hopkins opened their
season with Lehigh and, after
travelling up to Bethlehem, went
down to a 26-0 defeat. Without a
doubt, Lehigh is stronger than last
year. Just how much more so will
be seen.
Local fans are regaining some
of the enthusiasm which had been
lost during the past two seasons.
All agree that the Jays are much
stronger than last fall. Upsala was
unable to stop the locals' offensive
drives and the New Jersey attack
could not penetrate the Black and
Blue defense. Late in the last quarter they managed to gain against
the reserves, but against the varsity
they were held to a standstill.
Complaints

Although the majority of fans
seemed pleased with the lighting
system at Homewood, there are
quite a few discussions on the advisability of night football. Several
have complained that the use of
artificial light has robbed the game
of numerous thrills. However, it
is only fair to state that with one
or two exceptional plays, the Upsala
game last week would not have been
thrilling either in daylight or at
night.
Full Strength

Having come through the game
last week with only a few • minor
casualties, the Jays should be able
to present their full strength when
the teams line up for the opening
whistle. Mistakes were made last
week, as was to be expected. These
will be corrected during the week
and several rough spots will be
ironed out in the daily practices.
Jack Turnbull showed up in fine
style against the New Jerseyites
and was ably supported by Hudert,
Bauer, Reid and Reynolds. This
quintet of backs showed promise of
making things very uncomfortable
for opposing defenses as the season
progresses. On the line, Bialaskorsky seems to have taken up
where he left off last year when his
stellar work earned him a place at
tackle on the mythical All-Maryland
eleven. Levy, Helm, Weitzel and
Curtwright also played well. The
recovering of fumbles made by the
visitors showed that the Jays were
alert and "on their toes," while the
conspicuous absence of Jay fumbles
spoke well for their work when the
ball was in their possession.
All in all, there should be an interesting afternoon at the field to(Continued on page 4, col. 4)

EDITORIALS
CLASS ELECTIONS
N the editorial columns of various college newspapers we often meet
with pleas for a larger number of students to vote in the election of
class officers. At Hopkins we face the same problem. Only a small
fraction of the members of any class cast their ballots in the annual
elections. Then when the results are announced, the cry of dirty
campus politics inevitably arises. Let us investigate the matter.
As the time for nominations draws near there are usually one or
two prominent men in the class who are well qualified to fill a particular office. These men are nominated without any political move.
Some ambitious fraternity or other group will see to it that one of
its less able men is nominated. Election day arrives. The fraternities
or friends of the able men usually do little or no electioneering. They
take it for granted that their candidate will be elected because of his
qualifications for the office. On the other hand, the supporters of the
man not so well qualified, realizing that votes must be secured, proceed
to electioneer. Their methods _need not be discussed as they are well
known to every student. The votes are counted and a so-called "dark
horse" is elected. The cry of dirty politics arises.
This situation may easily be remedied. At present it is comparatively
easy to elect a man to an office which he does not deserve because
such a small number of votes are necessary to carry the election. The
very ones who complain the most are generally to blame. Some of
them say that the situation is hopeless and do not vote at all; others
cast their own ballot but never urge others to show their preference
on the ticket. If every student who is interested in any activity of
his class should vote, and see to it that others did the same, more able
class officers would undoubtedly be elected. At the same time we
would like to suggest that the able candidates be more actively supported by their friends.

BARNSTORMERS
night the Barnstormers held their annual rally. The results of
L AST
the changes of policy of the organization this year will be of

interest to all undergraduates. The chief problem is whether or not a
finished production can be prepared during the first semester. There
will be fewer conflicts the first week in December than during March
or April, and a larger audience may be expected. On the other hand,
concentrated work during October and November will be demanded.
The wiseness of this move is therefore questionable.
The innovation of having girls to take the female parts will remove
many a laugh from the annual show. On the other hand, it makes a
much better production possible. The NEWS-LETTER congratulates the
Barnstormers on attempting something new among the conservative
Hopkins activities, and wishes them the greatest success.

CONGRATULATIONS
improvements in the main reading room of Gilman Hall are
ASnow
complete, it is time to congratulate those responsible for

giving Hopkins one of the most beautiful college reading rooms in the
country. The bequest of Mrs. Mary King Carey, which made the erection of the windows possible, is certainly appreciated. The work of
Mr. J. Scott Williams in designing the windows was of the highest
order. Mr. W. L. Ross is deserving of praise for generously providing the means of making the furniture fit the beautiful windows.
Lastly, the endeavors of the University librarian, Dr. John Calvin
French, in supervising the work merit congratulations from all those
connected with Hopkins.

THE NIGHT FOOTBALL RACKET
By GEORGE E. BANKS,JR.'29
After much preliminary hoopla,
strong-armed publicity, and a brilliant display of showmanship, night
football has finally made its debut
on the Homewod campus. To advertise this nocturnal spectacle, the
master minds of the Athletic Department employed an ingenious device. They hired the steam calliope
which, for many months, has been
touring the downtown boulevards
making life miserable for the good
citizens of Baltimore. This same
contraption has been used to exploit the charms of the "Kuddling
Kuties" at the Gayety Theatre and
the antics of the demented cuckoos
who have been shuffling around
Carlin's dance pavilion for several
thousand hours. Thus, Hopkins
athletics take their place in the spotlight with the seductive burlesque
babies of East Baltimore Street and
the bleary-eyed nit-wits who are
participating in the dance marathon.
In spite of the calliope, several
thousand chilly football fans wended their way to Homewood field,
last Saturday night, to see what this
night football business is all about,
if anything. For two long hours,
they sat on concrete slabs, cooled
to the temperature of icebergs, and
watched something that looked a little bit like a football game. They
faced the cruel glare of six immense
arc lights which dazzled the eyes
like airport beacons. After the contest, plenty of the folks who followed the pied pipings of the calliope were wishing that they had
gone to a cozy movie parlor or
stayed home beside the steam radiator and listened to Rudy Vallee on
the radio. The next morning, when
they awake with stiff necks, sore
throats and snuffling noses, they
were even more certain that night
football is not a healthful diversion
for the humble spectator.
The big mystery, which no one
scems able to explain, is just why it
is necessary for Hopkins to play
football games after sunset. Certainly, there is no appreciable gain
to be made at the box office. Almost
every business man or factory laborer has a half-day holiday on Saturday. The student body does not
have to attend classes or work in
laboratories on Saturday afternoon.
Just as many people can attend in
the afternoon as night. Of course,
if the game conflicts with a strong
counter attraction at the Stadium,
there is some justification for an
evening game. But this situation
will occur but once this season.
Homewood Field has always provided a perfect setting for afternoon football games. The rich,
brilliant autumnal foliage of Wyman's Park forms a picturesque
background. The brisk, snappy
quality of the atmosphere is a real
tonic. One's eyes sparkle and cheers
for dear, old Alma Mater leap from
the throat spontaneously. The
football fan feels that it's good to
be alive. He trudges off to dinner
with a keen appetite, whetted by the
crisp, invigorating air.
Now, compare the afternoon
brand of weather with the dank,
chilly atmosphere which characterizes October and November nights.
The air is cold and penetrating. The
brightly colored trees are transformed into black, forbidding shadows. And the chances are two to
one that the fan will awaken the
next morning with a kink in his
neck.
Night football, as it is now being

played at Homewood, is grossly unfair to the visiting team. Upsala
gridders were muffing lots of balls
during the preliminary practice.
During the game, they seemed bewildered by the strong glare of the
arc lights.
On the other hand, the Jays can
practice under the lights every evening if they find it desirable to perfect their night game. They can
accustom themselves to the playing
conditions and shake off the strange
feeling of "unreality" which the
strong lights create.
But the visiting team, entirely
unaccustomed to these moonlight
monkeyshines, arrives on the scene
and has only twenty or thirty minutes to get used to the tricky playing conditions. Visiting players now
have a gilt-edge alibi to offer for
their defeats. There's small glory
awaiting the Jays in conquering
mystified foes that can't catch a
white football that looks as big as
a house. No wonder the Lehigh
team refused to play tomorrow's
contest in the blinding glare of the
arc lights.
In its present stage of development, night football takes its place
beside miniature golf as a freakish
novelty which is destined to live a
short life. For a little while, we
can expect to witness good crowds
at these night contests. But, after
the initial thrill has faded away, the
loyal fans will clamor for real football, played in the warm sunshine.
Wide open spaces will start to appear in the stands. Then, the wise
men who have to pay the electric
company's bill for the lighting system, will want to put a mortgage on
Gilman Hall.
